div.p: SOME writers have ≈øo confounded ≈øociety with government, as to leave little or no di≈øtinction between them; whereas, they are not only different, but have different origins. The one encourages intercour≈øe, the other creates di≈øtinctions. The fir≈øt is a patron, the la≈øt a puni≈øher.

Society in every ≈øtate is a ble≈ø≈øing, but Government even in its be≈øt ≈øtate is but a nece≈ø≈øary evil; in its wor≈øt ≈øtate an intolerable one: for when we ≈øuffer, or are expo≈øed to the ≈øame mi≈øeries by a Government, which we might expect in a country without Government, our calamity is heightened by
reflecting that we furni≈øh the means by which we ≈øuffer. Government like dre≈øs is the badge of lo≈øt innocence; the palaces of kings are built on the ruins of the bowers of paradi≈øe. For were the impul≈øes of con≈øcience clear, uniform, and irre≈øi≈øtibly obeyed, man would need no other lawgiver; but that not being the ca≈øe, he finds it nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øurrender up a part of his property to furni≈øh means for the protection of the re≈øt; and this he is induced to do, by the ≈øame prudence which in every other ca≈øe advi≈øes him, out of two evils to choo≈øe the lea≈øt. Wherefore, ≈øecurity being the true de≈øign and end of government, it unan≈øwerably follows, that whatever form thereof appears mo≈øt likely to en≈øure it to us, with the lea≈øt expence and greate≈øt benefit, is preferable to all others.

In order to gain a clear and ju≈øt idea of the de≈øign and end of government, let us ≈øuppo≈øe a ≈ømall number of per≈øons ≈øettled in ≈øome ≈øeque≈øtered part of the earth, unconnected with the re≈øt; they will then repre≈øent the fir≈øt peopling of any country; or of the world. In this ≈øtate of natural liberty, ≈øociety will be their fir≈øt thought. A thou≈øand motives will excite them thereto, the ≈øtrength of one
man is ≈øo unequal to his wants, and his mind ≈øo unfitted for perpetual ≈øolitude, that he is ≈øoon obliged to ≈øeek a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and relief of another, who in his turn requires the ≈øame. Di≈øea≈øe, nay even misfortune would be death; for tho' neither might be mortal, yet either would di≈øable him from living, and reduce him to a ≈øtate in which he might rather be ≈øaid to peri≈øh, than to die.

Thus nece≈ø≈øity like a gravitating power would ≈øoon form our newly arrived emigrants into ≈øociety, the reciprocal ble≈ø≈øings of which, would ≈øuper≈øede, and render the obligations of law and goverment unnece≈ø≈øary while they remained perfectly ju≈øt to each other: but as nothing but Heaven is impregnable to vice, it will unavoidably happen that in proportion as they ≈øurmount the fir≈øt difficulties of emigration, which

And however our eyes may be dazzled with ≈øhow, or our ears deceived by ≈øound; however prejudice may warp our wills, or intere≈øt darken our under≈øtanding, the ≈øimple voice of nature and of rea≈øon will ≈øay, 'tis right.

I draw my idea of the form of government from a principle in nature which no art can overturn, viz. That the more ≈øimple any thing is, the le≈øs liable it is to be di≈øordered, and the ea≈øier repaired when di≈øordered; and with this maxim in view I offer a few remarks on the ≈øo much boa≈øted con≈øtitution of England. Ab≈øolute governments, (tho' the di≈øgrace of human nature) have this advantage with them, that they are ≈øimple; if the people ≈øuffer, they know the head from which their

I know it is difficult to get over local or long ≈øtanding prejudices, yet if we will ≈øuffer our≈øelves to examine the component parts of the Engli≈øh con≈øtitution, we ≈øhall find them to be the ba≈øe remains of two ancient tyrannies, compounded with ≈øome new Republican materials.

The two fir≈øt by being hereditary are
independent of the People; wherefore in a con≈øtitutional ≈øen≈øe they contribute nothing towards the freedom of the State.
To ≈øay that the con≈øtitution of England is an union of three powers reciprocally checking each other, is farcical, either the words have no meaning or they are flat contradictions.
To ≈øay that the Commons are a check upon the King, pre≈øuppo≈øes two things.
Fir≈øt.‚ÄîThat the King is not to be tru≈øted without being looked after; or in other words, that a thir≈øt for ab≈øolute power is the natural di≈øea≈øe of Monarchy.

But as the ≈øame con≈øtitution which gives the Commons a power to check the King by with-holding the ≈øupplies, gives afterwards the King a power to check the Commons by empowering him to reject their other bills; it again ≈øuppo≈øes that the King is
wi≈øer than tho≈øe whom it has already ≈øuppo≈øed to be wi≈øer than him. A mere ab≈øurdity!

There is ≈øomething exceedingly ridiculous in the compo≈øition of Monarchy; it fir≈øt excludes a man from the means of information, yet empowers him to act in ca≈øes where the highe≈øt judgment is required.‚Äî The ≈øtate of a king ≈øhuts him from the world yet the bu≈øine≈øs of a king requires him to know it thoroughly: wherefore, the different parts by unnaturally oppo≈øing and de≈øtroying each other, prove the whole character to be ab≈øurd and u≈øele≈øs.

div.p: MANKIND being originally equals in the order of creation, the equality could only be de≈øtroyed by ≈øome ≈øub≈øequent circum≈øtance: the di≈øtinctions of rich and poor may in a great mea≈øure be accounted for, and that without having recour≈øe to the har≈øh ill-≈øounding names of oppre≈ø≈øion and avarice. div.head: APPENDIX TO COMMON SENSE. The nece≈ø≈øity of INDEPENDANCY.
div.p: SINCE the publication of the fir≈øt edition of this pamphlet, or rather on the ≈øame day on which it came out, the King's Speech made its appearance in this city. Had the ≈øpirit of prophecy directed the birth of this production, it could not have brought it forth, at a more ≈øea≈øonable juncture, or a more nece≈ø≈øary time. The bloody mindedne≈øs of the one, ≈øhew the nece≈ø≈øity of pur≈øuing the doctrine of the other. Men read by way of revenge. And the Speech, in≈øtead of terrifying, prepared a way for the manly principles of Independance.

Ceremony, and even ≈øilence, from whatever motive they may ari≈øe, have a hurtful tendency, when they give the lea≈øt degree of countenance to ba≈øe and wicked performances; wherefore, if this maxim
be admitted, it naturally follows, that the King's Speech, as being a piece of fini≈øhed villainy, de≈øerved, and ≈øtill de≈øerves, a general execration, both by the Congre≈øs and the people. Yet, as the dome≈øtic tranquillity of a nation, depends greatly on the cha≈øtity of what may properly be called NATIONAL MANNERS, it is often better, to pa≈øs ≈øome things over in ≈øilent di≈ødain, than to make u≈øe of ≈øuch new methods of di≈ølike, as might introduce the lea≈øt innovation, on that guardian of our peace and ≈øafety. And, perhaps, it is chiefly owing to this prudent delicacy, that the King's Speech hath not, before now, ≈øuffered a public execution. The Speech, if it may be called one, is nothing better than a wilful audacious libel again≈øt the truth, the common good, and the exi≈øtence of mankind; and is a formal and pompous method of offering up human ≈øacrifices, to the pride of tyrants. But this general ma≈ø≈øacre of mankind, is one of the privileges, and the certain con≈øequence of King's; for as nature knows them not, they know not her, and although they are beings of our own creating, they know not us, and are become the Gods of their creators. The ≈øpeech hath one good
quality, which is, that it is not calculated to deceive, neither can we, even if we would, be deceived by it. Brutality and tyranny appear on the face of it. It leaves us at no lo≈øs: And every line convinces, even in the moment of reading, that he, who hunts the woods for prey, the naked and untutored Indian, is le≈øs a Savage than the King of Britain.

Sir John Dalrymple, the putative father of a whining je≈øuitical piece, fallaciou≈øly called, "The addre≈øs of the people of England, to the Inhabitants of America," hath, perhaps, from a vain ≈øuppo≈øition, that the people here were to be frightened at the pomp and de≈øcription of a king, giving, (though very unwi≈øely on his part) the real character of the pre≈øent one: "But," ≈øays this writer, "if you are inclined to pay compliments to an admini≈øtration which we do not complain of, (meaning the Marquis of Rockingham's at the repeal of the Stamp Act,) it is very unfair in you to withhold them from that prince by who≈øe NOD ALONE, they were permitted to do any thing." This is toryi≈øm with a witne≈øs! Here is idolatry even without a ma≈øk: And he who can calmly hear and dige≈øt ≈øuch doctrine,
hath forfeited his claim to rationality‚Äî an apo≈øtate from the order of manhood, and ought to be con≈øidered‚Äîas one, who hath not only given up the proper dignity of man, but ≈øunk him≈øelf beneath the rank of animals, and contemptibly crawl through the world like a worm.

However, it matters very little now, what the king of England either ≈øays or does; he hath wickedly broken through every moral and human obligation, trampled nature and con≈øcience beneath his feet; and by a ≈øteady and con≈øtitutional ≈øpirit of in≈øolence and cruelty, procured for him≈øelf an univer≈øal hatred. It is now the intere≈øt of America to provide for her≈øelf. She hath already a large and young family, whom it is more her duty to take care of, than to be granting away her property, to ≈øupport a power, who is become a reproach to the names of men and chri≈øtians. ‚ÄîYE, who≈øe office it is to watch over the morals of a nation, of what≈øoever ≈øect or denomination ye are of, as well as ye, who, are more immediately the guardians of the public liberty, if ye wi≈øh to pre≈øerve your native country uncontaminated by European corruption, ye mu≈øt in ≈øecret wi≈øh a ≈øeparation.‚ÄîBut leaving
the moral part to private reflection, I ≈øhall chiefly confine my farther remarks to the following heads:
Fir≈øt, That it is the intere≈øt of America, to be ≈øeparated from Britain.
Secondly, Which is the ea≈øie≈øt and mo≈øt practicable plan, RECONCILIATION or INDEPENDANCE? with ≈øome occa≈øional remarks.

In ≈øupport of the fir≈øt, I could, If I judged it proper, produce the opinion of ≈øome of the able≈øt and mo≈øt experienced men on this continent; and who≈øe ≈øentiments, on that head, are not yet publicly known. It is in reality a ≈øelf evident po≈øition: For no nation, in a ≈øtate of foreign dependance, limited in its commerce, and cramped and fettered in its legi≈ølative powers, can ever arrive at any material eminence. America doth not yet know what opulence is; and although the progre≈øs which ≈øhe hath made, ≈øtands unparalleled in the hi≈øtory of other nations, it is but childhood, compared with what ≈øhe would be capable of arriving at, had ≈øhe, as ≈øhe ought to have, the legi≈ølative powers in her own hands.
England, is at this time, proudly coveting what would do her no good, were ≈øhe to accompli≈øh it; and the continent he≈øitating on a matter, which will be her final ruin if neglected. It is the commerce, and not the conque≈øt of America, by which England is to be benefited, and that would in a great mea≈øure continue, were the countries as independant of each other as France and Spain; becau≈øe in many articles, neither can go to a better market. But it is the independance of this country on Britain or any other, which is now the main and only object worthy of contention, and which, like all other truths di≈øcovered by nece≈ø≈øity, will appear clear and ≈øtronger every day.
Fir≈øt. Becau≈øe it will come to that one time or other.
Secondly, Becau≈øe the longer it is delayed, the harder it will be to accompli≈øh.

I have frequently amu≈øed my≈øelf both in public and private companies, with ≈øilently remarking the ≈øpecious errors of tho≈øe who ≈øpeak without reflecting. And among the many which I have heard, the following
≈øeems the mo≈øt general, viz. that had this rupture happened forty or fifty years hence, in≈øtead of now, the continent would have been more able to have ≈øhaken off the dependance. To which I reply, that our military ability at this time, ari≈øes from the experience gained in the la≈øt war, and which in forty or fifty years time, would have been totally extinct. The Continent would not, by that time, have had a General, or even a military officer left; and we, or tho≈øe who may ≈øucceed us, would have been as ignorant of martial matters as the ancient Indians: And this ≈øingle po≈øition, clo≈øely attended to, will unan≈øwerably prove, that the pre≈øent time is preferable to all others: The argument turns thus: At the conclu≈øion of the la≈øt war, we had experience, but wanted numbers; and forty or fifty years hence, we ≈øhould have numbers, without experience; wherefore, the proper point of time, mu≈øt be ≈øome particular point between the two extremes, in which a ≈øufficiency of the former remains, and a proper encrea≈øe of the latter is obtained: And that point of time is the pre≈øent time.

The reader will pardon this digre≈ø≈øion, as it does not properly come under the
head I fir≈øt ≈øet out with, and to which I again return by the following po≈øition, viz.

Should affairs be patched up with Britain, and ≈øhe to remain the governing and ≈øovereign power of America, (which as matters are now circum≈øtanced, is giving up the point entirely) we ≈øhall deprive our≈øelves of the very means of ≈øinking the debt we have, or may contract. The value of the back lands, which ≈øome of the provinces are clande≈øtinely deprived of, by the unju≈øt exten≈øion of the limits of Canada, valued only at five pounds ≈øterling per hundred acres, amount to upwards of twenty five millions, Penn≈øylvania currency; and the quit-rents at one penny ≈øterling per acre, to two millions yearly.

It is by the ≈øale of tho≈øe lands, that the debt may be ≈øunk, without burthen to any, and the quit-rent re≈øerved thereon, will always le≈ø≈øen, and in time will wholly ≈øupport the yearly expence of government. It matters not how long the debt is in paying, ≈øo that the lands when ≈øold, be applied to the di≈øcharge of it, and for the execution of which, the Congre≈øs for the time being, will be the continental tru≈øtees.
I proceed now to the ≈øecond head, viz. Which is the ea≈øie≈øt and mo≈øt practicable plan, Reconciliation or Independance; with ≈øome occa≈øional remarks.

He who takes nature for his guide, is not ea≈øily beaten out of his argument, and on that ground, I an≈øwer generally‚ÄîThat Independance being a ≈øingle ≈øimple line, contained within our≈øelves; and reconciliation, a matter exceedingly perplexed and complicated, and in which, a treacherous capricious court is to interfere, gives the an≈øwer without a doubt.

The pre≈øent ≈øtate of America is truly alarming to every man who is capable of reflection. Without law, without government, without any other mode of power than what is founded on, and granted by courte≈øy. Held together by an unexampled concurrence of ≈øentiment, which, is neverthele≈øs ≈øubject to change, and which, every ≈øecret enemy is endeavouring to di≈ø≈øolve. Our pre≈øent condition, is, Legi≈ølation without law, wi≈ødom without a plan, a con≈øtitution without a name, and, what is ≈øtrangely a≈øtoni≈øhing, perfect independance contending for dependance. The in≈øtance
is without a precedent; the ca≈øe never exi≈øted before; and who can tell what may be the event? The property of no man is ≈øecure in the pre≈øent unbraced ≈øy≈øtem of things. The mind of the multitude is left at random, and ≈øeeing no fixed object before them, they pur≈øue ≈øuch as fancy or opinion ≈øtarts. Nothing is criminal; there is no ≈øuch thing as trea≈øon; wherefore, every one thinks him≈øelf at liberty to act as he plea≈øes. The Tories would not have dared to a≈ø≈øemble offen≈øively, had they known that their lives, by that act, were forfeited to the laws of the ≈øtate. A line of di≈øtinction ≈øhould be drawn, between Engli≈øh ≈øoldiers taken in battle, and inhabitants of America taken in arms. The fir≈øt are pri≈øoners, but the latter traitors. The one forfeits his liberty, the other his head.

Notwith≈øtanding our wi≈ødom, there is a vi≈øible feeblene≈øs in ≈øome of our proceedings, which gives encouragement to di≈ø≈øentions. The Continental Belt is too loo≈øely buckled: And if ≈øomething is not done in time, it will be too late to do any thing, and we ≈øhall fall into a ≈øtate, in which, neither Reconciliation nor Independance will be practicable. The king and his worthle≈øs
adherents are got at the old game of dividing the Continent, and there are not wanting among us, Printers, who will be bu≈øy in ≈øpreading ≈øpecious fal≈øehoods. The artful and hypocritical letter, which appeared a few months ago, in two of the New-York papers, and likewi≈øe in two others, is an evidence, that there are men who want either judgment or hone≈øty.

It is ea≈øy getting into holes and corners, and talking of reconciliation: But do ≈øuch men ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øider, how difficult the ta≈øk is, and how dangerous it may prove, ≈øhould the Continent divide thereon. Do they take within their view, all the various orders of men, who≈øe ≈øituation and circum≈øtances, as well as their own, are to be con≈øidered therein. Do they put them≈øelves in the place of the ≈øufferer, who≈øe all is already gone, and of the ≈øoldier, who hath quitted all for the defence of his country. If their ill judged moderation be ≈øuited to their own private ≈øituations only, regardle≈øs of others, the event will convince them, that "they are reckoning without their ho≈øt."

Put us, ≈øay ≈øome, upon the footing we were on in ≈øixty-three: To which I an≈øwer, the reque≈øt is not now in the power of Britain to comply with, neither will ≈øhe propo≈øe it, but if it were, and even ≈øhould be granted, I a≈øk, as a rea≈øonable que≈øtion, By what means is ≈øuch a corrupt and faithle≈øs court to be kept to its engagements? Another parliament, nay, even the pre≈øent, may hereafter repeal the obligation, on the pretence of its being violently obtained, or unwi≈øely granted; and in that ca≈øe, Where is our redre≈øs?‚ÄîNo going to law with nations; cannon are the barri≈øters of crowns; and the ≈øword, not of ju≈øtice, but of war, decides the ≈øuit. To be on the footing of ≈øixty three, it is not ≈øufficient, that the laws only be put on the ≈øame ≈øtate, but that our circum≈øtances, likewi≈øe be put on the ≈øame ≈øtate; our burnt and de≈øtroyed towns repaired or built up, our private lo≈ø≈øes made good, our public debts (contracted for defence) di≈øcharged, otherwi≈øe, we ≈øhall be millions wor≈øe, than we were at that enviable period. Such a reque≈øt, had it been complied with a year ago, would have won the heart and ≈øoul of the Continent, but now it is too late. "The Rubicon is pa≈ø≈øed."

Be≈øides the taking up arms, merely to enforce the repeal of a pecuniary law, ≈øeems as unwarrantable by the divine law, and as repugnant to human feelings, as the taking up arms to enforce the obedience thereto. The object, on either ≈øide, doth not ju≈øtify the means; for the lives of men are too valuable, to be ca≈øt away on ≈øuch trifles. It is the violence which is done and threatened to our per≈øons; the de≈øtruction of our property by an armed force; the inva≈øion of our country by fire and ≈øword, which con≈øcientiou≈øly qualifies the u≈øe of arms: And the in≈øtant, in which ≈øuch a mode of defence became nece≈ø≈øary, all ≈øubjection to Britain ought to have cea≈øed; and the independancy of America, ≈øhould have been con≈øidered, as dating its aera from, and publi≈øhed by, the fir≈øt mu≈øket that was fired again≈øt her. This line is a line of con≈øi≈øtency; neither drawn by caprice, nor extended by ambition; but produced by a chain of events, of which the colonies were not the authors.

I ≈øhall conclude the≈øe remarks, with the following timely and well intended hints. We ought to reflect, that there are three different ways by which an independancy
may hereafter be affected; and that one of tho≈øe three, will one day or other, be the fate of America, viz. By the legal voice of the people in Congre≈øs; by a military power; or by a mob: It may not always happen that our ≈øoldiers are citizens, and the multitude a body of rea≈øonable men; virtue, as I have already remarked, is not hereditary, neither is it perpetual. Should an independancy be brought about by the fir≈øt of tho≈øe means, we have every opportunity and every encouragement before us, to form the noble≈øt pure≈øt con≈øtitution on the face of the earth. We have it in our power to begin the world over again. A ≈øituation, ≈øimilar to the pre≈øent, hath not happened ≈øince the days of Noah until now. The birth day of a new world is at hand, and a race of men, perhaps as numerous as all Europe contains, are to receive their portion of freedom from the event of a few months. The reflection is awful, and in this point of view, how trifling, how ridiculous, do the little, paltry cavillings, of a few weak or intere≈øted men appear, when weighed again≈øt the bu≈øine≈øs of a world.

Should we neglect the pre≈øent favorable and inviting period, and an independance
be hereafter effected by any other means, we mu≈øt charge the con≈øequence to our≈øelves, or to tho≈øe rather, who≈øe narrow and prejudiced ≈øouls, are habitually oppo≈øing the mea≈øure, without either inquiring or reflecting. There are rea≈øons to be given in ≈øupport of independance, which men ≈øhould rather privately think of, than be publicly told of. We ought not now to be debating whether we ≈øhall be independant or not, but, anxious to accompli≈øh it on a firm, ≈øecure, and honorable ba≈øis, and unea≈øy rather that it is not yet began upon. Every day convinces us of its nece≈ø≈øity: Even the Tories (if ≈øuch beings yet remain among us) ≈øhould, of all men, be the mo≈øt ≈øolicitous to promote it; for as the appointment of committees at fir≈øt, protected them from popular rage, ≈øo, a wi≈øe and well e≈øtabli≈øhed form of government, will be the only certain means of continuing it ≈øecurely to them. Wherefore, if they have not virtue enough to be WHIGS, they ought to have prudence enough to wi≈øh for Independance.

In ≈øhort, Independance is the only BOND that can tye and keep us together. We ≈øhall then ≈øee our object, and our ears will be legally ≈øhut again≈øt the ≈øchemes of an intriguing,
as well, as a cruel enemy. We ≈øhall then too, be on a proper footing, to treat with Britain; for there is rea≈øon to conclude, that the pride of that court, will be le≈øs hurt by treating with the American ≈øtates for terms of peace, than with tho≈øe, whom ≈øhe denominates, "rebellious ≈øubjects," for terms of accommodation. It is our delaying in that, encourages her to hope for conque≈øt, and our backwardne≈øs tends only to prolong the war. As we have, without any good effect therefrom, withheld our trade to obtain a redre≈øs of our grievances, let us now try the alternative, by independantly redre≈ø≈øing them our≈øelves, and then offering to open the trade. The mercantile and rea≈øonable part in England, will be ≈øtill with us; becau≈øe, peace with trade, is preferable to war without it. And if this offer be not accepted, other courts may be applied to.

On the≈øe grounds I re≈øt the matter. And as no offer hath yet been made to refute the doctrine contained in the former editions of this pamphlet, it is a negative proof, that either the doctrine cannot be refuted, or, that the party in favor of it are too numerous to be oppo≈øed. WHEREFORE, in≈øtead
of gazing at each other with ≈øu≈øpicious or doubtful curio≈øity, let each of us hold out to his neighbour the hearty hand of friendship, and unite in drawing a line, which, like an act of oblivion ≈øhall bury in forgetfulne≈øs every former di≈ø≈øention. Let the names of Whig and Tory be extinct; and let none other be heard among us, than tho≈øe of a good citizen, an open and re≈øolute friend, and a virtuous ≈øupporter of the RIGHTS of MANKIND and of the FREE AND INDEPENDANT STATES OF AMERICA.

div.head: To the Repre≈øentatives of the Religious Society of the People called Quakers, or to ≈øo many of them as were concerned in publi≈øhing a late piece, entitled The ANCIENT TESTIMONY and PRINCIPLES of the People called QUAKERS renewed, with re≈øpect to the KING and GOVERNMENT, and touching the COMMOTIONS now prevailing in the≈øe and other parts of AMERICA addre≈ø≈øed to the PEOPLE IN GENERAL.
div.p:
THE Writer of this, is one of tho≈øe few, who never di≈øhonors religion either by ridiculing, or cavilling at
any denomination what≈øoever. To God, and not to man, are all men accountable on the ≈øcore of religion. Wherefore, this epi≈øtle is not ≈øo properly addre≈ø≈øed to you as a religious, but as a political body, dabbling in matters, which the profe≈ø≈øed Quietude of your Principles in≈øtruct you not to meddle with.

As you have, without a proper authority for ≈øo doing, put your≈øelves in the place of the whole body of the Quakers, ≈øo, the writer of this, in order to be on an equal rank with your≈øelves, is under the nece≈ø≈øity of putting him≈øelf in the place of all tho≈øe, who, approve the very writings and principles again≈øt which, your te≈øtimony is directed: And he hath cho≈øen this ≈øingular ≈øituation, in order, that you might di≈øcover in him that pre≈øumption of character which you cannot ≈øee in your≈øelves. For neither he nor you can have any claim or title to Political Repre≈øentation.

When men have departed from the right way, it is no wonder that they ≈øtumble and fall. And it is evident from the manner in which ye have managed your te≈øtimony, that politics, (as a religious body of men) is not your proper Walk; for however well adapted it might appear to you, it is, neverthele≈øs,
a jumble of good and bad put unwi≈øely together, and the conclu≈øion drawn therefrom, both unnatural and unju≈øt.

The two fir≈øt pages, (and the whole doth not make four) we give you credit for, and expect the ≈øame civility from you, becau≈øe the love and de≈øire of peace is not confined to Quakeri≈øm, it is the natural, as well as the religious wi≈øh of all denominations of men. And on this ground, as men laboring to e≈øtabli≈øh an Independant Con≈øtitution of our own, do we exceed all others in our hope, end, and aim. Our plan is peace forever. We are tired of contention with Britain, and can ≈øee no real end to it but in a final ≈øeparation. We act con≈øi≈øtently, becau≈øe for the ≈øake of introducing an endle≈øs and uninterrupted peace, do we bear the evils and burthens of the pre≈øent day. We are endeavoring, and will ≈øteadily continue to endeavor, to ≈øeparate and di≈ø≈øolve a connection which hath already filled our land with blood; and which, while the name of it remains, will be the fatal cau≈øe of future mi≈øchiefs to both countries.

We fight neither for revenge nor conque≈øt; neither from pride nor pa≈ø≈øion; we
